notesStmt.note: On A2r: last word in first line of text: 'and'; first word under initial: 'His'; last word in last full line of text: 'Conside'.
Identified as part of Wing (2nd ed.) E874 on reel 1758; entry cancelled in Wing (CD-ROM).

Reproductions of the originals in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery (Early English books, 1641-1700, reel 1259), and the Union Theological Seminary, New York (Early English books, 1641-1700 reel 1758).

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: AN ACT For the Security of HIS HIGHNES THE LORD PROTECTOR His Per≈øon, And Continuance of the Nation in Peace and Safety.
div.p:
FOra≈ømuch as the pro≈øperity and ≈øafety of this Nation, and the Dominions thereunto belonging, very much dependeth (under God) upon the ≈øecurity and pre≈øervation of the Per≈øon of His Highne≈øs; And for that it hath manife≈øtly appeared, that divers wicked Plots and means have been of late devi≈øed and laid, as well in Foreign parts beyond the Seas, as al≈øo within this Nation, to the great endangering His Highne≈øs Per≈øon, and the embroyling this Commonwealth in new and inte≈øtine Wars, and Seditions, to the utter Ruine and Subver≈øion thereof, if the ≈øame had taken effect. Therefore, and for the preventing of ≈øuch great Perils and Mi≈øchiefs as may hereafter en≈øue, by the like dete≈øtable Con≈øpiracies and Practi≈øes; The Parliament, sout of a deep Sen≈øe and Con≈øideration
thereof, do de≈øire that it may be Enacted and Ordained, And be it Enacted and Ordained by His Highne≈øs the Lord Protector, and the Parliament, and the Authority thereof, That if any per≈øon or per≈øons ≈øhall from and after the Tenth day of October, in the year of our Lord, One thou≈øand ≈øix hundred fifty and ≈øix, Attempt, Compa≈øs, or Imagine the death of the Lord Protector; And ≈øuch Attempting, Compa≈ø≈øing, or Imagining ≈øhall declare by open deed; Or ≈øhall levy War, or Plot, Contrive, or Endeavour to ≈øtir up, or rai≈øe Force again≈øt the Lord Protector, or the Government, to ≈øubvert or alter the ≈øame, and ≈øhall by open Deed declare ≈øuch Endeavour, Plotting or Contriving; Or ≈øhall advi≈øedly and maliciou≈øly Proclaim, Declare, Publi≈øh, or Promote Charles Stuart, elde≈øt Son to the late King, or any other I≈ø≈øue or Po≈øterity of the ≈øaid late King, or any other per≈øon, claiming by, from or under him, any, or either of them, to be King, Queen, or Chief Magi≈øtrate of Great Brittain, or of England, Scotland, or Ireland, or of any the Dominions thereto, or to any of them belonging; Or ≈øhall be Aiding, A≈ø≈øi≈øting, Comforting, or Abetting unto any per≈øon or per≈øons, that ≈øhall by any ways, or means what≈øoever, endeavour or attempt the reviving, or ≈øetting up of any pretended Right, Title, or Claim of the ≈øaid Charles Stuart, or of any other the I≈ø≈øue or Po≈øterity of the ≈øaid late King, or of any per≈øon or per≈øons claiming under him, or them, to any of the Offices, Stile, Title, Dignity, or Authority afore≈øaid, or any of them; Or ≈øhall hold any Intelligence or Corre≈øpondence with the ≈øaid Charles Stuart, or with James Stuart, or Henry Stuart, or with
the late Queen their Mother, or any, or either of them; Or ≈øhall give or contribute any ≈øum or ≈øums of Money, or other Aid or A≈ø≈øi≈øtance to the ≈øaid Charles Stuart, or unto James and Henry Sons of the ≈øaid late King, or to the late Queen their Mother, or to any or either of them; Or ≈øhall Plot, Contrive, or Endeavour the Betraying, Surrendring, or Yeelding up any City, Town, Ca≈øtle, Fort, Magazine, Ship, Ve≈ø≈øel, or Forces by Land, or by Sea, belonging to this Common-wealth, unto the Enemies thereof; Or ≈øhall advi≈øedly and maliciou≈øly Plot, Contrive, or Endeavour by any open Act, to ≈øtir up Mutiny in the Army or Fleet, or among≈øt any of the Forces thereof, by Sea or Land, to withdraw any Officer or Souldier, Mariner or Sea-man, from his or their obedience to the Lord Protector; Or ≈øhall Invite, Procure, Aid, or A≈ø≈øi≈øt any Forreigner, or Stranger to invade the≈øe Nations of England, Scotland, or Ireland, or any the Dominions thereto belonging; Or ≈øhall Adhere to any Forces rai≈øed, or that ≈øhall be hereafter rai≈øed again≈øt the Lord Protector of this Common-wealth; Then all and every the Offences above mentioned ≈øhall be, and are hereby Deemed, Ordained, and Adjudged to be High Trea≈øon. And that in all ≈øuch Ca≈øes, and upon all ≈øuch occa≈øions the Lord Chancellour, Lord Keeper, or Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners of the Great Seal of England, for the time being, are hereby Authorized and required from time to time, by Warrant from His Highne≈øs the Lord Protector, to i≈ø≈øue out one or more Commi≈ø≈øion or Commi≈ø≈øions under the Great Seal of England, to the re≈øpective per≈øons hereafter named, That is to
≈øay; For England and Wales, the Town of Barwick upon Tweed, and the I≈øles of Guern≈øey and Jer≈øey, The Lord Chancellour, Lord Keeper, or Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners of the Great Seal of England for the time being; The Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners of the Trea≈øury for the time being; The Chief Iu≈øtice of the Vpper Bench; The Ma≈øter of the Rolls; The Chief Iu≈øtice of the Common-Pleas; The Chief Baron of the Exchequer; The Iu≈øtices of the Vpper Bench; The Iu≈øtices of the Common-Pleas, The Barons of the Exchequer, and every of them for the time being, Li≈ø≈øebone Long E≈øq Recorder of the City of London, Roger Hill Serjeant at Law, Unton Crook Serjeant at Law, Era≈ømus Earl Serjeant at Law, George Lord Eure, Sir William Strickland, William Earl of Salisbury, Sir Walter St. John Baronet, Sir Chri≈øtopher Pack, Sir Thomas Vyner, Sir John Dethick, Robert Tichburn, Thomas Foot, John Ireton, Aldermen of the City of London, Sir John Hobart Baronet, Sir William Roberts, Sir John Thoroughgood of Ken≈øington, Sir John Copple≈øton, Sir Thomas Pride, Sir John Bark≈øtead Lieutenant of the Tower of London, Luke Robin≈øon E≈øq Anthony Rous E≈øq John Hilde≈øley E≈øq Alexander Blake E≈øq Owen Row E≈øq Henry Hat≈øel E≈øq Edward Cre≈øset E≈øq Richard Lucy E≈øq John Fothergill E≈øq Thomas Whitegrave E≈øq Charles George Cock one of the Iudges of the Admiralty, John Godolphin Doctor of the Laws, one of the Iudges of the Admiralty, Captain John Brown of Orpington, Dennis Bond E≈øq Sir Richard Combes, John Mar≈øh E≈øq Adam Wa≈øhington, Francis Clinton, alias Fiennes, John Ward, Richard Dunton, James Chadwick, Bu≈øsey Man≈øel, E≈øqs Sir George Eleetwood of the County
of Bucks Knight, Nicholas Green E≈øq Thomas Bendi≈øh E≈øq Sir John Trever, William Underwood Alderman of the City of London, Arthur Stanhope E≈øq Sir Francis Ru≈øsel Baronet, John Bingham E≈øq Thomas Croxton. Dudley Templer, Richard Lilburn E≈øqs John James of Trippleton in the County of Hereford E≈øq Thomas Dicken≈øon E≈øq Alderman of the City of York, Samuel Moody E≈øq Richard Boughton, William Freeman, George Downing, John Hagget, Bennet Hoskins, John Corbet, William Foxwi≈øt, Edward Bul≈øtrode, Evan Seys, E≈øqs Robert Wood of Breadona≈øh in the County of Norfolk E≈øq Anthony Nicoll, Azariah Husbands, John Pitman, Chri≈øtopher Li≈øter, John Carter, Robert Jermy, Peter Legay, Henry Cannon, E≈øqs John Geldart, Alderman of York, John Palmer Doctor of Phy≈øick, Francis La≈øsels, John Stone, Alban Cox, John Grew of Bedford, E≈øqs Cornelius Holland, Peter Ceeley, James Dewey, Henry Barrington, E≈øqs John Crofts, Wroth Rogers, William Cullen, Abraham Babington, William Puckle, Charles Doyley, Edward Herbert, Henry King, Thomas Brooks, Nicholas Saltar, E≈øqs Robert Weaver of Am≈øtrey in the County of Hereford E≈øq John Gorges E≈øq Thomas Ba≈ønet Alderman of Coventry, Robert Aldworth, Jo≈øeph Hawk≈øworth, John Fiennes, George Byard, Edward Clud, E≈øqs Richard Fincher, John Carey of Dichley E≈øqs Edmund Waring E≈øq Thomas Allen Alderman of the City of London, Robert Ca≈øtle, Thomas Gorges, Robert Shap≈øcot, E≈øqs Thomas Pury junior E≈øq John Price, James Philips, William Put, John Spadman, William Shield, E≈øqs
Sir John Read Baronet, John Upton, Ralph Rymere, E≈øqs Walter Biggs Alderman of London, William Goffe E≈øq Francis Hacker, Hezekiah Haines, John Bi≈øcoe, E≈øqs William Boteler of Oundle E≈øq
Francis Underwood, George Gwyn, Henry Williams, E≈øqs
Sir Thomas Honiwood, William Purefoy E≈øq James Hely of Salisbury E≈øq
or any ≈øeventeen or more of them. And for Scotland, Roger Lord Broghill, General George Monk, Charles Howard of Naworth E≈øq
Sir Edward Rhodes, John Swinton, Adrian Scroop, Samuel Disbrow, Nathaniel Whetham, E≈øquires: Ceorge Smith, William Lawrence, Edward Mo≈øely, Henry Goodier, E≈øqs
Sir James Lermount of Bacomy, Alexander Peir≈øon, Andrew Ker, E≈øqs John Earl of Tweedale, Sir John Weyms of Bogy, Sir Andrew Ker of Greenhead, Sir James Macdowel, Sir Alexander Wedderburn, John Lockart E≈øq Alexander Dowgla≈øs Doctor of Phy≈øick, David Barckley, Andrew Ram≈øey, Alexander Jeffery, E≈øqs
Lord Strenever, Richard A≈øhfield, Thomas Talbot, Timothy Wilks, Leonard Lidcot, Edmund Syler, William Gough, Steven Winthrop, Jo≈øeph Strange, E≈øqs Charles Fairfax of Men≈øton E≈øq John Ma≈øon E≈øq
_____ Davis E≈øq Roger Sawry E≈øq Peter Cri≈øp E≈øq Ralph Knight E≈øq Thomas Read E≈øq Henry Whalley, William Daniel, Ralph Cobbet, Richard Mayor, Abraham Holmes, John Peir≈øon, Noel Butler‚ñ™ Miles Man, William Packer, Thomas Morgan, William Michel, Thomas Fitch, Jeremy Tolhur≈øt, E≈øqs Robert Fenwick of Bedlington E≈øq Sir Wilfrid Law≈øon, William Fenwick of Wallington E≈øq Luke Killingworth, Captain John Ogle of Kittley, Henry Hor≈øley of Milburn Graunge, E≈øqs Thomas Bonner, George Daw≈øon, William John≈øon, Aldermen of Newca≈øtle upon Tine, John Toppin, Edward Fenwick of Stanton, E≈øqs William Bri≈øcoe E≈øq
or any thirteen or more of them. And for Ireland, The Lord Chancellour, Chief Iu≈øtices of either Bench, Chief Baron, the Iu≈øtices of either Bench, the Barons of the Exchequer, and every
of them for the time being, Robert Goodwin‚ñ™ Matthew Thomlin≈øon, William Bury E≈øqs
Sir James Barry, Arthur Hill, Vincent Gookin, William Jeph≈øon, Henry Markam, John Hew≈øon, Richard Lawrence, Thomas Cooper, Thomas Sadler, Jeremy Zankey, Henry Pritty, E≈øqs

Sir Theophilus Jones, Sir Robert Meredith. Sir John Temple, Sir Robert King, Sir Hardre≈øs Waller, Solomon Richards the younger, Sir William Fenton, Henry Ingoldsby, George Ingoldsby, John King E≈øqs Richard Tigh Alderman of Dublin, John Bret, Henry Owen, Francis Bolton, Tri≈øtram Berrisford, Morris Fenton, Robert Southwell, Sir Charles Coot, Childley Coot, Robert Ormsby, John Percival, Thomas Southwell, William Warden, Daniel Redman, Nicholas Purdon, Francis Fowlks, Walter Waller, Thomas Herbert, John Bice Recorder of Dublin, Anthony Morgan, Richard Blany, William A≈øton, Edward Roberts, James Standi≈øh, John Vernon, William Duckenfield, Peter Wallis, Daniel Abbot, Robert Saunders, Peter Stubber, William Hal≈øey, Ralph King, William Arnop, John Nel≈øon, John Bridges, Henry Jones, John Cook, James Trail, or any thirteen, or more of them.

p.q: I A. B. do ≈øwear, That I will well and truly, according to the be≈øt of my skill and knowledge, execute the ≈øeveral Powers given unto me and others, by a Commi≈øsion under the Great Seal of England, i≈ø≈øued out in pur≈øuance of an Act, Entituled, An Act for the Security of His Highne≈øs the Lord Protector His Per≈øon, and Continuance of the Nation in Peace and Safety.

div.p:
And the Lord Chancellor, Lord Keeper, or Lords Commi≈øsioners of the Great Seal of England for the time being, or any of them, are hereby authorized to admini≈øter the ≈øaid Oath accordingly to the ≈øaid Commi≈øsioners for England and Wales, Town of Berwick upon Tweed, and I≈øles of Guern≈øey and Jer≈øey, And the Lord Deputy, Chancellor, Pre≈øident of the Councel of Ireland, or any one of them, are hereby authorized to admini≈øter the ≈øaid Oath accordingly to the ≈øaid Commi≈øsioners for Ireland: And the Pre≈øident, or any one or more of the Council of Scotland, are hereby authorized to admini≈øter the ≈øaid Oath accordingly to the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners for Scotland, Provided, That the ≈øaid re≈øpective Commi≈ø≈øioners, or any of them, ≈øhall not by vertue or force of this Pre≈øent Act, or any Power thereby given unto them, examine try or proceed again≈øt any per≈øon or per≈øons,
other then ≈øuch who ≈øhall be fir≈øt by name appointed by the Lord Protector, with the advice and con≈øent of his Council, to be by them the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners ≈øo examined, tryed or proceeded again≈øt. Provided alwaies, and it is hereby further enacted, That this Act, and the Powers and Authorities hereby given, ≈øhall continue and remain in force from henceforth, untill the end of the la≈øt Se≈ø≈øion of the next Parliament, and no longer.
LONDON: Printed by Henry Hills and John Field, Printers to His Highne≈øs. 1657.
